story: The Labour leader said Theresa May&rsquos negotiating strategy is leading the UK down the wrong path but when asked whether he would stop the split if he could, he said: &ldquoWe can't stop it.Labour members overwhelmingly backed leaving the door open to a second referendum at the party&rsquos conference in September.And activists campaigning for a final say on the orce deal have been hoping Mr Corbyn will eventually cave to public pressure and support another vote.But the Labour leader, who is a well-known Eurosceptic, today insisted Brexit cannot be stopped.READ MORE: Jo Jonson quits Government over Brexit - leaving EU is 'terrible mistake'                Brexit news: Stanley Johnson INSTANTLY reacts to son&rsquos resignation                 Theresa May could deliver CRUCIAL Brexit finalised speech by next weekIn an interview with German magazine Der Spiegel he said: The referendum took place. Article 50 has been triggered. What we can do is recognise the reasons why people voted Leave.Asked whether he felt sorry for Mrs May given her &ldquoimpossible task of striking a deal with Brussels while trying to reconcile the Leave and Remain wings of the Tory party, Mr Corbyn said: I am a decent human being, I feel sorry for anyone in distress.But the best way for anyone to alleviate distress is to take yourself away from the source of it.He said if he was leading the exit talks, Labour would be pushing for a new customs union deal with the EU which he said would protect UK jobs.Follow Express below for live Brexit updates:Brexit news: Jeremy Corbyn has insisted Britain's orce from the EU 'can't be stopped' (Image:  IMAGES)9pm: A look forward to next weekJo Johnson&rsquos resignation and the DUP&rsquos warning over her Irish border plans have topped off a difficult week for Theresa May on the Brexit front - but next week promises to be even tougher.The Prime Minister is likely to meet with her Cabinet on Monday or Tuesday for crunch talks over the orce deal.Senior ministers have been invited to view the text of the withdrawal agreement already signed off with Brussels - said to be 95 percent of the deal - but a solution to the Irish border issue still has not been reached.While&nbspMrs&nbspMay attempts to convince the Cabinet to back her plan, negotiations will continue to attempt to reach a compromise on the border &lsquobackstop&rsquo.European Council President Donald Tusk said yesterday the final issues could be &ldquomaybe be resolved in as little as five days but may take as long as a week.Theresa May will attempt to convince ministers to back her Brexit plans next week (Image:  IMAGES)8pm: We don&rsquot need a second referendum to deliver Brexit - just BACKBONEJacob Rees-Mogg has reacted to the departure of Jo Johnson, who warned Theresa May&rsquos Brexit strategy would result in either EU vassalage or chaos caused by no deal.But the prominent Brexiteer disputed Mr Johnson&rsquos claim that a second referendum should be held.Mr Rees-Mogg tweeted: &ldquo@JoJohnsonUK is right to resign over the Withdrawal Agreement which does not deliver on the referendum but creates a vassal state.&ldquoIt does not need a second referendum but backbone to deliver Brexit.7.10pm: Brexit &lsquocan&rsquot be stopped&rsquo, Corbyn declaresJeremy Corbyn has dented hopes for a second referendum by insisting Britain&rsquos exit from the European Union is inevitable.Mr Corbyn is a well known Eurosceptic but some campaigners pushing for a second referendum have been hoping for the Labour leader to change tack and back calls for a public vote on the final deal.Asked by German magazine Der Spiegel if he would stop Brexit if he could, the Labour leader said: We can't stop it.The referendum took place. Article 50 has been triggered. What we can do is recognise the reasons why people voted Leave.DUP leader Arlene Foster said her party would vote against Mrs May's Brexit plans as they stand (Image:  IMAGES)                Jo Johnson resigns: Who is Jo Johnson? Why has he quit?                &lsquoDo NOT cave into Brussels&rsquo Fears EU boats will fish in UK waters6.20pm: &lsquoMore talks needed&rsquo before Brexit deal reachedEU negotiators have dented hopes of an imminent breakthrough on Britain&rsquos orce deal, saying more work is needed before an agreement is reached.Diplomats familiar with a briefing between the Michel Barnier&rsquos team and envoys from member states said &ldquomore talks are required.Reports by European media this week suggested the impasse over the Irish border issue is close to being overcome and a deal could be signed off by EU leaders at an emergency summit later this month.5.35pm: No second referendum under ANY circumstancesTheresa May has responded to Jo Johnson&rsquos resignation and his calls for a public vote on the final deal by insisting there will be no second referendum.The Prime Minister's spokesman said: The referendum in 2016 was the biggest democratic exercise in this country's history.&ldquoWe will not under any circumstances have a second referendum. The Prime Minister thanks Jo Johnson for his work in government.Meanwhile, Boris Johnson has reacted to his brother&rsquos departure as transport minister.He wrote in a tweet: Boundless admiration as ever for my brother Jo. We may not have agreed about Brexit but we are united in dismay at the intellectually and politically indefensible of the UK position.This is not taking back control. It is a surrender of control. It does not remotely correspond to the mandate of the people in June 2016.The two brothers campaigned on opposite sides of the Brexit debate in the run-up to the 2016 vote.                Brexit SPLIT: Leaked letter reveals MASSIVE EU concession by May                Labour&rsquos &lsquoIMAGINARY&rsquo Brexit deal MOCKED by journalist on Question Time5.05pm: No deal is still better than a bad deal, says David DavisDavid Davis has warned the withdrawal agreement on offer &ldquolooks like a bad deal.The Former Brexit Secretary said a hard Brexit which would see the UK fall back onto World Trade Organisation rules after the split would be better than accepting the Brussels&rsquo terms.Responding to reports that the EU is demanding continued access to British fishing waters and Theresa May has included a clause which would create a border down the Irish sea, Mr Davis said in a tweet: If reports are true regarding concessions on fishing and a border in the Irish Sea, then this is not the Brexit that people voted for.&ldquoIf the EU will not negotiate in good faith then we must assume that WTO is still better than what looks like a bad deal.Boris Johnson's brother, Jo, has resigned as transport minister over Brexit (Image:  IMAGES)4.30pm: DUP warns it will vote AGAINST Brexit deal as it standsArlene Foster has threatened to vote against any Brexit deal which includes a Northern Ireland-specific backstop.The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader said &ldquono unionist would be able to support Theresa May&rsquos plans.Negotiators are still working to reach an agreement on the Irish &lsquobackstop&rsquo which would kick in to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland if no deal is struck.But the DUP is committed to avoiding any deal which could result in Northern Ireland being treated any differently from the rest of the UK after Brexit.And the party has interpreted a promise made by May in a letter that she would never let a ision of the UK to come into force as an admission that such a clause would be included in a final deal.Ms Foster said: In other words,&nbspNorthern Ireland will have a different regulatory system from the rest of the United Kingdom, and essentially there's going to be a border down the Irish Sea.3.55pm: Jo Johnson QUITS over Brexit - leaving on May&rsquos terms &lsquowill be a terrible mistake&rsquoBoris Johnson&rsquos brother Jo has resigned over the Government&rsquos Brexit strategy and backed a second referendum giving the British people a say over the final deal.Jo Johnson, who served as Minister of State for the Department for Transport, said it &ldquowill be a terrible mistake if the orce deal is finalised.The MP for Orpington branded Theresa May&rsquos Brexit vision &ldquodelusional and said the split being proposed is nothing like what was promised before the referendum.In his resignation statement, Mr Johnson, who backed Remain in 2016, said: &ldquoBritain stands on the brink of the greatest crisis since the Second World War.Given that the reality of Brexit has turned out to be so far from what was once promised, the democratic thing to do is to give the public the final say.Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones warned of damage to Welsh ports in the event of a no-deal Brexit (Image: PA)3.15pm: No-deal Brexit could hammer Welsh ports, warns Carwyn JonesLeaving the European Union without a deal in place could be hugely damaging to ports in Wales, Carwyn Jones has warned.The Welsh First Minister said 70 percent of trade between Great Britain and Ireland passes through Welsh ports like Holyhead and failure to strike a free trade agreement with Brussels could put that business at risk.His warning came as Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar warned a no-deal Brexit could mean freight from Ireland bound for the continent may have to move through sea routes to French, Dutch and Belgian ports instead of the quicker &ldquoland bridge via Britain to Calais.Speaking at the end of the British-Irish Council summit on the Isle of Man,&nbspMr&nbspJones said: The last thing I would like to see is a hard border between Ireland and Wales.If there is extra bureaucracy, extra checks at Welsh ports, that will have an effect on the ports themselves and the road infrastructure leading into the ports, both of which are devolved.We run the ports and the roads.There is a danger, if we have a hard Brexit with no deal, that we end up having to pay a huge amount of money on the port and on the roads in order to accommodate the traffic that would be delayed there as a result of an imposition of extra controls.Harvey Gavin taking over from Katie Harris on live reporting.2.45pm update: Nicola Sturgeon says Brexit highlights UK&rsquos devolution weaknessesBrexit has highlighted real weaknesses in the UK's devolution settlement, according to Scotland&rsquos First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.Ms&nbspSturgeon said: I will make no bones about the fact that the Brexit experience has exposed real weaknesses within the devolution settlement that will require them to be worked through and resolved along the way.                Brexit news: David Davis RIPS into Remainers calling for second vote                 Brexit news: Dominic Raab under fire for Dover-Calais trade comment2pm update: Hammond rejects Northern Ireland-only backstopChancellor Philip Hammond has insisted the UK cannot be split up.Mr Hammond said to the BBC: We've always said that we can't accept the Commission's proposal for a Northern Ireland-specific solution, because we are Unionists and we won't agree anything which puts our Union at risk.So we've spent most of this year negotiating an alternative backstop, which allows us to give the European Commission the insurance policy that they are looking for without threatening to break up our Union.Nicola Sturgeon said Brexit highlights UK&rsquos devolution weaknesses (Image: PA)12.40pm update: Irish Prime Minister says Brexit negotiations are at sensitive pointIreland&rsquos Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has said a Brexit deal is possible within weeks.Speaking at the British-Irish Council summit in the Isle of Man, Mr Varadkar said: We are at a sensitive point in the negotiations.A successful outcome is not guaranteed but I think it is possible in the next couple of weeks.11.50am update: German Economy Minister &ldquooptimistic about Brexit dealGermany&rsquos Economy Minister Peter Altmaier has said he is &ldquooptimistic a Brexit deal can be made, in a major boost to Mrs May as she faces high pressure from the DUP as well as ongoing isions within her own party.Speaking in Berlin, Mr Altmaier said: I am optimistic that a Brexit deal can be achieved and will be achieved.Ireland&rsquos Taoiseach Leo Varadkar said a Brexit deal is possible within weeks (Image: REUTERS)10.55am update: DUP piles pressure on Mrs May in row over Irish backstopDUP minister Sammy Wilson has refused to confirm if the DUP would back key Budget legislation next week as the row over the Northern Ireland backstop escalates.Asked by Ireland's RTE radio whether the DUP would support the bill, Mr Wilson said: &ldquoWe will be making our decisions on how we progress.We are saying nothing ... other than to say time and time again that there will be consequences if the government breaks its side of the bargain.Sammy Wilson accused Mrs May of a &ldquototal betrayal (Image: )10.15am update: EU pushes ahead with no-deal preparationsThe EU is refusing to halt its no-deal preparations despite a Brexit deal being within reach.The bloc will continue to push its contingency plans until a deal is signed off by UK politicians and European Parliament.An EU source said: &ldquoEven if we have an agreement and champagne is flowing over glasses, everyone happy with cheeky, red faces we don&rsquot know if the deal enters into force.&ldquoThe withdrawal agreement still needs the parliamentary OK from the EU and UK parliaments.&ldquoWe will continue till March with our contingency work.Dominic Raab (right) is furious with David Lidington (Image: )9.45am update: Raab furious with May's deputy David LidingtonDominic Raab is &ldquofurious with Theresa May&rsquos deputy David Lidington over the Cabinet Office Minister&rsquos attempts to push a softer Brexit in dealings with Ireland, it has been claimed.Mr Lidington has been working with Ireland&rsquos Taoiseach Leo Varadkar and Foreign Minister Simon Coveney in the final stages of Brexit negotiations between the UK and EU.But Mr Raab accused Mr Lidington of &ldquogoing behind his back, according to the Brexit Secretary&rsquos allies.One senior Conservative told the Sun: Dominic is furious. He feels he is being undermined at every turn.&ldquoThe Government is being run by Philip Hammond, Greg Clark and David Lidington. And they all want to stay in the customs union.8.45am update: Culture Secretary denies PM will accept Northern Ireland-only backstopCulture Secretary Jeremy Wright has insisted the Prime Minister would not accept a deal that includes a Northern Ireland-only backstop.Speaking to BBC Radio 4, Mr Wright said: Were there to be a border down the Irish Sea, as I've said and the Prime Minister has said, we wouldn't accept a deal incorporating that.What's important is we get a deal that satisfies our requirements - and by our requirements I mean the whole of the United Kingdom, including Northern Ireland.We don't have that proposed deal yet. story: Bank of England (Image: ADRIAN DENNISAFPGetty Images)Growth of 0.6 per cent was recorded for the July to September period, up from 0.4 per cent in the previous quarter and 0.1 per cent in the first three months of the year.&nbspThe latest figures mark the fastest quarterly growth since the last three months of 2016 when it measured 0.7 per cent, said the Office for National Statistics. They also mean year-on-year growth sped up to 1.5 per cent, compared to 1.2 per cent in the April to June period.                Brexit BOOST: Dominic Raab 'thumbs up' causes pound to ROCKETChancellor Philip Hammond, whose recent Budget announced public finances were in a much stronger state than expected, declared: Today's positive growth of 0.6 per cent is proof of the underlying strength in our economy.&nbspWe are building an economy that works for everyone with 3.3 million more people in work, lower unemployment in every part of the country, and wages rising at their fastest pace in almost a decade.&nbspNow our focus is on locking in this progress and ensuring people's wages can continue to rise.That is why my Budget supports hardworking families by cutting taxes for 32 million people, provides more funding for public services, including a record-breaking funding increase for our vital NHS, and invests in our future with more money for transport and digital technology.Latest figures show fastest quarterly growth since the end of 2016 (Image: Education ImagesUIG via Getty Images)Strong retail sales during the football World Cup and heat wave, and a recovery in construction in July were the main factors behind the growth boost, which was in line with expectations of the Bank of England and economists.Meanwhile the Government has announced 11 overseas investment deals worth a total of &pound109million.They are expected to create 359 high tech, advanced engineering and banking jobs in London, Leeds, Newcastle and Reading.They were secured with help from Liam Fox's Department for International Trade, which is working to boost Britain's global trade links, exports and foreign investment in the UK as Britain prepares to regain control over over its trade policies after Brexit.British Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond and the 2018 Budget  (Image: ADRIAN DENNISAFPGetty Images)Several of the new investments come from fast-growing Asian and Latin American markets including India, Brazil and Argentina as well as the United States.Dr Fox said: It's easy to see why the UK is Europe's top destination for foreign direct investment.&nbspOur country is home to world leading research and development capability, as well as a culture of innovation.My international economic department has a network of Trade Commissioners operating across the world, seeking investment opportunities that will help create jobs and improve the lives of people in the UK.VITAL: NHS (Image: TOLGA AKMENAFPGetty Images)As we celebrate the Lord Mayor's Parade in the City of London, today's announcement is further evidence that the UK is one of the most attractive places in the world to invest and demonstrates a vote of confidence in our economy and our people.The new deals include digital, artificial intelligence and information technology developments.Dr Fox's department also yesterday announced &pound345million in UK Export Finance support for UK firms to build three new hospitals and upgrade two power stations in Angola.This is&nbsp a great example of how our ambition to grow exports is helping British businesses break into overseas markets, said Trade Minister Baroness Fairhead.The projects include a Mother and Child Hospital and a general hospital to be built by the UK branch of international construction firm ASGC.The IQA Group based in Paisley, Scotland, with a Spanish parent company,&nbsp is celebrating its first international contract, to upgrade two power stations which will significantly reduce Angola's reliance on oil-generated energy and improve citizens' access to electricity.Yesterday's ONS figures showed construction and manufacturing output picked up in the third quarter of 2018 after a weak start to the year thanks to bad weather.Increased car-making contributed to narrowing the gap between Britain's exports and imports, though new car sales in September were hit by new emission regulations restricting supply.Trading information at the London Metal Exchange Ltd. (LME) (Image: Simon DawsonBloomberg via Getty Images)Household spending was also up, though the dominant services sector grew only 0.3 per cent and business investment shrank by 1.2 per cent, blamed on uncertainty about whether the UK will be able to strike a good Brexit deal with Brussels in time for leaving the bloc on March 29.Some economists also believe the economy has peaked for the year, after a strong July was followed by no extra growth in August and September, and the pound was largely unmoved by the ONS bulletin.Rob Kent-Smith, head of national accounts at the ONS, said: The economy saw a strong summer, although longer term economic growth remained subdued.&nbspThere are some signs of weakness in September with slowing retail sales and a fall-back in domestic car purchases.However, car manufacture for export grew across the quarter, boosting factory output.Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England (BOE), second left, speaks during the bank's quarterly  (Image: Chris RatcliffeBloomberg via Getty Images)Meanwhile, imports of cars dropped substantially, helping to improve Britain's trade balance.&nbspThe Bank of England's latest report predicted growth will drop back to 0.3 per cent in the final months of this year before rising again to steady at 0.4 per cent.The National Institute of Economic and Social Research expects the economy to expand by 0.4 per cent between last month and the end of the year, more in line with Britain's post-financial crisis average.Forecasting chief Amit Kara added: The outlook for growth is particularly uncertain, especially with the exit date from the European Union fast approaching and the terms of the future relationship yet to be settled.BREXIT: British pounds and Euros (Image: Omar MarquesSOPA ImagesLightRocket Getty Images)The EY ITEM club has a gloomier prediction of 0.3 per cent growth in the last quarter of this year, resulting in overall GDP expansion in 2018 of 1.3 per cent, a nine-year low.&nbspHowever, chief economic advisor Howard Archer added: We forecast GDP growth to strengthen to 1.5 per cent in 2019, supported by a gradual improvement in consumer purchasing power and modestly firmer business investment as a UK-EU transition arrangement is assumed to come into effect in March.He noted that despite a worrying drop in business investment in the third quarter, overall investment expanded 0.8 per cent compared to the previous three months, helped by a marked increase in Government investment.Net trade made a substantial contribution of 0.8 percentage point to third quarter GDP growth having been a substantial drag in the second quarter.&nbspThe City of London, global financial hub (Image: Tim GrahamGetty Images)Exports of goods and services rebounded 2.7 per cent quarter-on-quarter in the third quarter after a drop of 2.2 per cent in the second quarter, he noted.Consumer purchasing power should benefit as inflation is seen averaging a reduced 2.1 per cent in 2019 while earnings growth is expected to trend up gradually.Meanwhile business investment may be supported by some firms looking to increasingly invest in automation to make up for labour shortages and try to boost productivity.Suren Thiru, head of economics at the British Chambers of Commerce, warned: It remains likely that the stronger growth recorded in the third quarter is a one-off for the UK economy, with persistent Brexit uncertainty and the financial squeeze on consumers and businesses likely to weigh increasingly on economic activity in the coming quarters.

story: The European Space Agency (ESA) released groundbreaking satellite images which reveal a whole new set of information regarding the ancient continents, going back as much as 180 million years ago. According to ESA, these masses are just one mile (1.6km) underneath Antartica, but they have never been traced before. mission to find life on Enceladus                NASA asteroid WARNING: Asteroid will pass Earth closer than MoonFausto Ferraccioli, Science Leader of Geology and Geophysics at the British Antarctic Survey, said: &ldquoThese gravity images are revolutionising our ability to study the least understood continent on Earth: Antarctica.&nbsp&ldquoIn East Antarctica, we see an exciting mosaic of geological features that reveal fundamental similarities and differences between the crust beneath Antarctica and other continents it was joined to until 160 million years ago.Among the groundbreaking discoveries ESA made, there is new information on Gondwana, a supercontinent that housed what is now Antarctica.According to ESA, Antarctica and Australia remained linked as recently as 55 million years ago, despite the landmass splitting about 130 years ago.&nbspScience news: ESA released groundbreaking satellite images (Image: ESA)Science news: Earth's continents 160 million years ago (Image: ESA)ESA was also able to reveal West Antarctica has a thinner crust than East Antarctica.This discovery links this side of the southern icy continent to Australia and India, as they share with it the type of crust.ESA used vital data gathered by the Gravity field and Ocean Circulation Explorer (GOCE), the first ESA&rsquos satellite which mapped the Earth&rsquos gravity field from 2009 to 2013, when it plummeted into Earth after it ran out of fuel.The images helped scientists to map put the movements of Earth&rsquos tectonic plates under Antartica.&nbsp                NASA asteroid WARNING: planet&rsquos lithosphere, the so-called crust and molten boiling mantle of the Earth.But these findings may help not just to examine Antarctica but also to have a &ldquofresh look on Earth.GOCE mission scientist Roger Haagmans said: &ldquoIt is exciting to see that direct use of the gravity gradients, which were measured for the first time ever with GOCE, leads to a fresh independent look inside Earth &ndash even below a thick sheet of ice.&ldquoIt also provides context of how continents were possibly connected in the past before they drifted apart owing to plate motion.&nbsp&nbsp

checks at the Welsh ports, that will have an effect on the ports themselves, and of course on the road structure leading to the ports, both of which are devolved.&ldquoNow we run the ports, we run the roads, there is a danger that if we had a hard Brexit with no deal, for example, that we would end up having to pay a huge amount of money on the port and on the roads in order to accommodate the traffic that we delay there as a result of any extra controls.The First Minister of Wales added: &ldquoSo it&rsquos hugely important for us in Wales to avoid that.Even after a withdrawal agreement between the EU and UK has been concluded, Brussels will continue its preparations for Britain leaving the bloc without a deal.Brexit news: a no-deal Brexit would cost a huge amount of money for Wales (Image: BBCGetty)Officials will not halt their no-deal preparations until the final withdrawal deal is signed off by politicians in the House of Commons and the European Parliament.One senior EU diplomat said the bloc&rsquos no-deal contingency planning will continue until March 29 2019 when Britain officially leaves.The source said: &ldquoEven if we have an agreement and champagne is flowing over glasses, everyone happy with cheeky, red faces we don&rsquot know if the deal enters into force.&ldquoThe withdrawal agreement still needs the parliamentary OK from the EU and UK parliaments.&ldquoWe will continue till March with our contingency work.Brussels&rsquo powerful executive body, the EU Commission, has once again intensified its no-deal preparations by organising high-level briefings for member states next week.The seminars will focus on the consequences on transport, financial services and citizens&rsquo rights if Britain leaves the EU without an agreement.The European Commission&rsquos 12 seminars will kickoff on November 20 and will be held in private.

story: Theresa May is close to an agreement with the EU on the backstop agreement (Image: )The UK is insisting there should be a review mechanism which will allow Britain to pull out of the backstop and ensure they are not forced to abide by EU rules indefinitely. According to Bloomberg, citing people close to the negotiations, both sides have come to an agreement on what the review mechanism should look like. EU ambassadors were briefed yesterday on the plans.                BREXIT BOOST: UK economy growing at FASTEST rate for two years                May&rsquos TOUGHEST opponent could sink Brexit NOW - &lsquoSHAKY GROUND!'Theresa May has been pushing for a review mechanism after Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab demanded reassurances the UK would not find themselves indefinitely in a transition period tied to EU rules.In a statement on Monday the Ireland leader, or Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar admitted he was willing to consider such a proposal.A statement following a meeting between Mrs May and Mr Varadkar said: &ldquoThe Taoiseach indicated an openness to consider proposals for a review, provided that it was clear that the outcome of any such review could not involve a unilateral decision to end the backstop.In fresh hopes that a deal is about to be reached it is reported both sides of the negotiation have now agreed a mechanism that would allow the UK and EU to mutually terminate the backstop agreement.Dominic Raab has demanded reassurances about the backstop agreement (Image: )Mrs May is desperate for a summit to sign off the withdrawal agreement to be held by the end of the month and negotiations in Brussels are expected to continue over the weekend and next week to finalise details of the deal.However, the review mechanism is likely to fall short of expectations among some Government Ministers who will be angry the UK will have to consult the EU and get their agreement before pulling out of the backstop.EU officials are said to be concerned Mrs May will be unable to convince her Cabinet to sign up to the deal.Mrs May is also reported to be close to agreeing a deal on the customs union with Brussels, however, this agreement is also set to face anger at home.                Barnier NEEDS to be worried: Shippers warn EU will LOSE                Jacob Rees-Mogg demands Theresa May show &lsquoBACKBONE&rsquo in Brexit talksArlene Foster has reacted furiously to what she sees a a betrayal of Northern Ireland (Image: )In a letter to the DUP leaked to the media, the Prime Minister suggested she could sign a deal which would tie Northern Ireland to the European customs union and single market if future talks collapse.Mrs May&rsquos letter claimed the EU is demanding a &ldquobackstop to the backstop, which would keep Northern Ireland tied to the customs union to prevent a hard border with the Irish Republic should the UK as a whole pull out of the initial backstop without a deal.While the Prime Minister said she would not allow the second backstop to &ldquocome into force, her letter failed to rule out it being a part of the finalised agreement.DUP leader, Arlene Foster, expressed outrage at the proposals.She told The Times: &ldquoThe Prime Minister&rsquos letter raises alarm bells for those who value the integrity of our precious Union and for those who want a proper Brexit for the whole of the UK.&ldquoIt appears the Prime Minister is wedded to the idea of a border down the Irish Sea with Northern Ireland in the EU single market regulatory regime.However, on Thursday a Government source said reports of an imminent Brexit deal should be taken with &ldquoa very large pinch of salt.

title: life on mars ancient city alien red planet ufo sightings proof
story: Conspiracy theorists have been on the hunt to prove NASA has been lying to the public about life on Mars. Now, one may have revealed some evidence which seemingly shows an ancient structure on the Red Planet. The image, taken by NASA satellites hovering over Mars, appears to depict ancient structures and even stone carvings.                UFO spotted on MercuryIn the picture, which includes annotations, walls look as if they appear to have been built as if they are part of a fortress,Prominent alien hunter Scott C Waring says this is &ldquo100 percent proof that life does, or did, exist on the Red Planet.He wrote on his blog, UFO Sightings Daily: &ldquoI found a lot of ancient structures in a Mars photo today. These structures are long and almost resemble walls, but are buildings in long lines.&ldquoI also discovered a face carved into a hill top, but is so ancient, it may be hard for some to see its details.&ldquoThis is 100 percent proof that ancient civilisations once flourished on the surface of Mars, and that NASA doesn't want you to know about it.&lsquoANCIENT city&rsquo on Red Planet is &lsquo100 percent proof&rsquo of aliens (Image: UFO SIGHTINGS DAILY)Supposed walls on Mars (Image: UFO SIGHTINGS DAILY)Sceptics and NASA would say the &lsquocity&rsquo and other similar findings are just the effects of pareidolia &ndash a psychological phenomenon when the brain tricks the eyes into seeing familiar objects or shapes in patterns or textures such as a rock surface.This is not the first time that &lsquoevidence&rsquo of aliens on Mars has been discovered.Earlier this year, an alien face was found in a NASA satellite image of Mars, according to more bonkers claims.Mr Waring was convinced it could be a rock carving, done by a Martian race, in the same way ancient Britons carved out the chalk figures in hillsides like the giant of Cerene Abbas in Dorset and the Long Man of Wilmington in East Sussex.An alien face carving (Image: UFO SIGHTINGS DAILY)However, NASA insisted the rock is just a meteorite impact crater that has been left in the unusual form by later erosion.When NASA released the image under the alien head caption, it said: The image shows an impact crater in Chryse Planitia, not too far from the Viking 1 lander site, that to seems to resemble a bug-eyed head.The two odd depressions at the north end of the crater (the &lsquoeyes&rsquo) may have formed by wind or water erosion.This region has been modified by both processes, with water action occurring in the distant past via floods that poured across western Chryse Planitia from Maja Valles, and wind action common occurrence in more recent history.

story: Last month, Brittany Ferries said it feared 70,000 of the freight units it ships annually to the continent will be affected by stringent, and punitive, inspections of British goods which could be initiated at Calais, warning of possible job losses as a result.&nbspAnd in July Xavier Bertrand, the President of France&rsquos Hauts-de-France region, warned of &ldquoeconomic catastrophe in the event of a hard Brexit.&nbspThere are fears of huge tailbacks on motorways on either side of the channel. title: Italy news Matteo Salvini European Commission Brussels Italian Budget 2019
story: The eurosceptic Deputy Prime Minister claimed Italian citizens would never accept the Commission to sanction Italy over the rejected Budget proposal of their Government. The Italian Interior Minister pledged the controversial budget plan will be submitted unchanged.&nbsp                Italy FIGHTS back: Salvini warns Merkel eurosceptics will save Europe                EU heading for euro CRISIS as Italy budget CANNOT be stoppedHe said: &ldquoWe can add more investments to the budget, as we have experienced the bad weather of the last few days, not because Brussels asks us to but because if mountains start crumbling more money is needed.&ldquoBut the parameters won&rsquot change, the measures on jobs, taxes, education and police forces won&rsquot change.&ldquoI don&rsquot think that a Commission with removal boxes and packed suitcases ready to leave could lecture Europe or Italy after years of disasters.&ldquoWe go ahead with total serenity and tranquillity.Italy news: Matteo Salvini vows rejected Budget proposal will not change (Image: VISTA&bull)&ldquoIf anyone in Brussels thinks they can commission or sanction us they got it wrong.&ldquoItalian citizens would never accept it.Brussels is concerned Rome's budget proposals would increase Italy&rsquos public debt burden due to the planned boost in spending.The bloc demanded Rome comes up with a revised budget, but Italy has continued to insist it must increase its deficit to 2.4 percent, which breaks EU fiscal rules designed to protect the Eurozone.Commissioner Mr&nbspMoscovici&nbspsaid: &ldquoI want a dialogue, but sanctions can be finally applied if we cannot reach an agreement.&ldquoOn the 13th of November we expect a strong, precise answer from the Italian government.Mr Moscovici said the next step for Italy depends on the country&rsquos budget response.He has said: &ldquoThe ball is now in Italy&rsquos court.&ldquoMember states must fully respect national democratic choices, but they should not run counter to our rules.

story: Emmanuel Macron is &lsquoriding a wave of fear&rsquo, fumes Marine Le Pen                Macron TORN APART by furious pensioner over botched tax reformMr Macron tried, somewhat in vain, to defend his track record.&nbsp&ldquoThere are days when people are angry. Look at me &ndash I&rsquom very happy. I never thought it would be easy.His trip, however, was nearly ruined by a controversy surrounding Marshal Philippe P&eacutetain, a general who subsequently became a top collaborator with the Nazi regime in World War Two.&nbspMr Macron angered France&rsquos Jewish community on Wednesday after he said that Marshal P&eacutetain was a &ldquogreat soldier even through he had made &ldquodisastrous choices during the Nazi occupation of France.&nbspBut government spokesman Benjamin Griveaux later denounced a &ldquofalse controversy, saying that the &ldquoglory Marshal P&eacutetain earned in Verdun during the first world war &ldquocan be neither contested nor go unrecognised by the nation.&nbspBritish PM Theresa May met Macron today (Image: Christopher Furlong WPA PoolGetty Images)The president&rsquos so-called battlefield tour ends this Sunday, when around 70 leaders including US President Donald Trump, Russian President Vladimir Putin, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, meet in Paris to attend ceremonies marking the centennial of the end of the first world war.&nbspMost leaders &ndash excluding Mr Trump &ndash will also take part in a peace summit hosted by Mr Macron later in the day.&nbspThe young centrist, who has repeatedly warned of rising nationalism and positioned himself as a defender of democracy, warned earlier this week that &ldquopeace in Europe is precarious.&nbsp

title: second referendum labour keir starmer
story: While Theresa May has continually ruled out holding a second vote, many have thrown their weight behind another vote on our EU status. Heres the latest.While a number of politicians and celebrities have added their voice to growing calls for a second referendum this has always been rejected by Downing Street.Earlier today, Jo Johnson resigned as rail minister and said the deal was substantially worse than staying in the EU, and it was imperative we go back to the people and check they still want to leave.Upon resigning, Johnson demanded a second referendum.His decision to resign came after the failure of Brexit negotiations to achieve what had been promised.In September  the mayor of Manchester Andy Burnham backed a second Brexit votethere was a no-deal scenario - but warned it could trigger social unrest.Theresa Mays official spokesman has said: The British people have voted to leave the EU and there is not going to be a second referendum under any circumstances.It could depend on how Brits perceive Parliamentary squabbles over Mrs Mays Chequers deal.Labour has been in a muddle over the issue too — with the leadership refusing to commit to a call for a second vote despite cries from centrist MPs and members.A sizeable section in the party want a second referendum and pressure is mounting on the left-wing leader.The GMB, one of the UKs biggest trade unions, called for a vote on the final Brexit deal.Later in September , Mayor of London Sadiq Khan dramatically called for another EU referendum — saying that people must be given the opportunity to reject Brexit.The Mayor of London, who is an avowed remainer, argued Britain is facing either a bad deal or “no deal” which he says will hit jobs and living standards.Referring to the worst case scenerios, Mr Khan said: “They are both incredibly risky and I don’t believe Theresa May has the mandate to gamble so flagrantly with the British economy and people’s livelihoods.”Labours official position is that it would vote against any deal struck by Theresa May with the aim of pushing for a General Election.Shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer said that a motion on the highly isive question that has dominated the event in Liverpool doesnt rule out Remain.He told Labours party conference: We want a General Election to sweep away this failed government.After the Peoples Vote rally in central London Keir Starmer reaffirmed the party have also not ruled out calling for a second Brexit referendumthey couldnt force and election.Speaking on the BBCs Andrew Marr, he said: “If there’s no deal brought back or the deal is voted down, then other options are on the table, one of which is a public vote.“And in that public vote no options are ruled out, including the option of remain.”Paddy Power has odds of   on another EU referendum before the end of .A poll carried out by NatCen and The UK in Changing Europe revealed  per cent of voters would now vote to remain in the EU, while  per cent would opt to leave.The author of the poll John Curtice urged caution over the finding.He said the interview  was skewed towards remain, and that some of the sht was among those who did not take part in the original Brexit referendum.On November  , it was reported that the majority of voters in all seats held by Labour support a second referendum on Brexit.The findings were according to an analysis released by the People’s Vote campaign from a YouGov poll of , people.A second referendum will not happen quickly and the first stage is for there to be an Act of Parliament.That will require the backing of a majority of MPs and it took seven months before Parliament signed off the previous referendum legislation in .Last time around there was a four-month period between the then Prime Minister David Cameron announcing the referendum in February , and the vote taking place on  June.But the Electoral Commission has said in future there should be at least a six-month gap allow enough time to register campaigns and put counting officers in place.There is also the question of what to do about Article .Britain could vote to remain in the EU, but have  already left by the time the vote was held.This could be avoidedthe EU agreed to extend the Article  deadline - but that would need to be unanimously agreed by all EU member states.Then there is the question of what to put on the ballot paper.If there are three questions for example accept a negotiated Brexit deal, stay in the EU, or leave with no deal then just  per cent could decide the winning option. The first referendum on EU membership took place in .Two-thirds of votersbacked the continued membership of the European Economic Community, which the UK had joined only two years before.Under Harold Wilsons leadership, the Labour Party was trying to present to the public a dferent version of EEC membership to get a better deal.The EEC was integrated into the European Union after it was created in .In the summer of , Britain voted to leave the EU after .million people backed Leave compared to .million Remain voters.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teenagers who repaired a vandalised tommy statue in devon are true brits not the grenfell effigy morons
story: If so, three news stories in the past week might suggest Britain is standing just one millimetre away from the clf face of irretrievable, mass inhumanity.Firstly, let’s turn to the pond le who constructed a cardboard model of Grenfell Tower — complete with cut-outs of adults and children in the windows — and set fire to it. One female onlookershrieks, “Help me! Help me!” as the others laugh, while someone  boasts: “I made the burning people.”It’s not just that it’s shockingly distasteful, it’s the sheer callousness of it that renders one almost speechless with disbelief.Then there’s the group of lads in their late teens who thought it funny to spit at Janice Morris as she sat alone on a park bench, before later pelting her with flour and eggs.When police — who class her as vulnerable and with mental health issues — visited her Suffolk home later that day, they found her still covered in flour and with “smudged mascara down her face”.One of the gang — -year-old Cohan Semple — saw fit to take a photo of the attack and posted it on Snapchat.One recipient reposted it to Facebook, it went viral and, quite rightly, prompted widespread revulsion and a police investigation.All five have pleaded guilty to using threatening behaviour which caused harassment, alarm or distress and await sentencing.Meanwhile, it seems “dozens” of the Remembrance Day “Silent Silhouette” statues placed all over the country have been defaced or smashed up by mindless vandals. In Devon alone, one statue was snapped in half, another five vandalised and one stolen.Oh how we wish that,caught in the act, their punishment could be a few weeks on the frontline of a war zone. But don’t hold your breath.Instead, let’s focus on the good in society that, thankfully, still forms the majority. The thousands who expressed their abject disgust at the breathtakingly inhumane bonfire stunt, the horried locals in Bury St Edmunds who helped police locate Miss Morris and bring her tormentors to justice, and the noble volunteers who, seeing the damage to the Silent Silhouette statues, stepped in to repair them in time for this weekend’s Remembrance Sunday.Volunteers such as a group of teenagers in Axminster, Devon, who took a vandalised “Tommy” in to their school workshop and repaired him.Placing him back at the scene afterwards, they laid a wreath and declared: “We are here today to show you that we, as young people, do care.“We care about the sacrices made by the brave men and women who fought for our country.”So let’s take comfort that the true measure of British society lies in their actions and not those of a few morons.“Dry Martini service trolley”, anyone  Nope, me neither.As for the hand-stitched couture Valentino gown, the site describes it as “a dress that defies adjectives”.Oh, I don’t know. “Bloody expensive” comes to mind.MODEL and self-publicist extraordinaire Emily Ratajkowski has published this photo with the caption: “Laundry day.”Cripes. Let’s hope she hits the delicates setting for that T-shirt, as there ain’t too much scope for further shrinkage.Oh dear. Will you tell her or shall I A “CHILD” refugee is under investigation by the Home Office after his fellow pupils at an Ipswich school posted a pic online with the caption: “How’s there a -year-old man in our maths class ”Their suspicions were aroused after finding a Facebook profile in the same name with photos of a man swigging beer while sporting a thick moustache and chest hair. A simple check that took just a few seconds and should have been made by the authorities before they placed him at the school.It seems wily teenagers aren’t anything like as daft as their supposed superiors.The nation clearly needs to get out more.WHILE his estranged we Lisa Armstrong was in court for the initial hearing of their orce, Ant McPartlin was strolling in a park with new love Anne-Marie Corbett and Labrador Hurley.In photos, the canoodling couple appear to be on their own, but in yesterday’s Sun it was reported that, at one stage, “an aide handed Ant a poo bag”. In the interests of clarity, one should perhaps point out the bag was for the dog, not Ant himself. But I digress.The aide’s role reminds me of the old joke about the circus worker whose job it was to clean up prolic amounts of elephant dung.When asked whether he’d ever considered another line of work, he replied: “What – and give up showbiz ”THIS photo of Tom Cruise reprising his role as Maverick for the Top Gun sequel suggests he hasn’t aged at all in the intervening -plus years.Or perhaps it’s simply the wonderfully flattering gravitational pull of a high-speed motorbike.YOU know you’re famous when your No fan is Adele.When she appeared on James Corden’s Carpool karaoke, she was word-perfect on the Spice Girls single Wannabe and said she dreamed of being Ginger Spice.And yesterday, when four of the ladiesannounced a reunion tour, the delightfully down-to-earth Ms Adkins posted a photo of herself, pictured, aged about seven, in front of her bedroom wall papered in their posters and with the caption: “I am ready.”For Adele’s now thirty-something generation, you can’t overestimate the effect of the Spice Girls when they burst on to the pop scene in  with Wannabe.Yes, the “girl power” mantra was a bit cheesy but the point is that for a while they defined the zeitgeist of social change for girls who saw these feisty, opinionated young women having fun primarily on their own terms – and aspired to do the same.They’ve all had their trials and tribulations in the ensuing years . . . but haven’t we all Most of all, the Spice Girls are a mirror of the enduring power of female friendship, with all its twists, turns, complexities, bickering, sniping Mel B and Victoria – who, by the way, are currently speaking and, ultimately, longevity.Welcome back ladies. We’ve missed you.BARONESS Warsi has criticised hit TV series Bodyguard for its “stereotypical” portrayal of Muslim women.“Either she’s downtrodden and needs to be saved or she’s a terrorist and we need to be saved from her,” she says.“In Bodyguard, we think she’s one and she turns out to be the other.”It seems writer Jed Mercurio – criticised by others for being too politically correct – just can’t win.Perhaps he should go back to the drawing board and follow the stereotypes of just about every other crime drama, where the killer always turns out to be a white, middle-aged man.Perhaps they should send a copy to the current crop of largely incompetent candidates on The Apprentice.LOVE Island winners Jack and Dani have moved in together and are reportedly arguing over the smallest things.In other words, the honeymoon period is over and the pair have now moved into the more realistic phase of what is commonly referred to as the long-term relationship.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: how might brexit affect my european holiday everything you need to know
story: But how much will leaving the EU really have an impact on our much-loved European holidays after we go It all depends on whether Britain is able to seal a withdrawal deal with the bloc in the next few weeks.If we can, then things should stay almost exactly the same after we officially leave next March - as we will enter a -month transition period.And after that the real hard work begins on a trade deal and a series of new agreements. Buttheres No Deal, then things could get tricky.Ministers are still working on getting a crucial agreement signed soon, but they could have to implement emergency plans in just days time. What should you know about getting ready for your holidays As part of plans to get ready for No Deal, it was recommended that Brits with less than a year left on their passport get theirs renewed sooner rather than later.Ministers said British people will need to have a passport which is valid for at least six monthsthey want to visit the EU.After we quit the EU our passports will be a navy blue colour, not the current burgundy red.Gloomy Phil Hammond got the nation panicking when he said that under No Deal, planes could be grounded between Britain and the EU. Its a warning thats been repeated by countless politicians since, including the EUs Jean Claude Juncker.Britain would no longer be in the EUs single aviation market, and flights to other countries with which the EU has a deal would also be affected.New agreements can be negotiated, but they could take a while.Airlines are confident that flights will continue to take off regardless - EasyJet and British Airways have said an agreement will be put in place, but Ryanair has been a little more cautious and has begun warning passengers on tickets that it cant be guaranteed.Trains will still run after Brexit, of course. But there are no guarantees that Eurotunnel wont have any disruption next year.As part of a raft of No Deal notices last month, the Government said that companies such as Eurostar, which only holds a UK licence, could be affected unless inidual agreements are struck with the countries it goes to.It advises taking out insurance for Eurostar tickets that cover any Brexit disruption.Under No Deal, UK driving licences would no longer be valid in the EU so holidaymakers would need to buy an international driving permit, available at the Post Office for £..The Government said: You may be turned away at the border or face other enforcement action, for example fines,you don’t have the correct IDP.And you could need a Green card  too - a translation of your car insurance policy - which you can get from the Post Office.But providing ministers secure the -month transition period as planned, this should stay the same.Holidaymakers are delaying booking their ferry crossings for next summer because of Brexit fears, Brittany Ferries said earlier this week, with bookings down  per cent.Dover to Calais and other ferry routes could be impactedchecks have to be made at borders in the event of a No Deal Brexit.But there are unlikely to be any extra delays for tourists, as Brits already get their passports checked en route anyway.No changes should be needed for anyone booking a package deal - unless your booking is with an EU-based firm and made outside the UK, in which case you may not be protected.There was a drop in the pound after Britain voted to leave the EU, meaning Brits will have to stump up more money to get their euros when going abroad on the continent.Buttheres a Brexit deal signed in the next few weeks, the pounds value could increase and make next years a bit cheaper again. A No Deal could see it drop again, pushing up prices.Brits will be able to continue to enjoy free healthcare when travelling in Europe after Brexit, it was confirmed last year.As part of the Withdrawal Agreement, officials have negotiated to use the European Health Insurance Cardacross EU’s  remaining member states – not just the country they’re living in.Pet owners should speak to a vet as soon as possiblethey want to take their animals to Europe after Brexit, Britains top vet warned earlier this week.Brits will need to pay up to £ for the right to take pets on holidaywe leave the EU with No Deal.If we do get a deal in the next few weeks it should be able to continue as normal.Most UK networks say they have no plans to bring back roaming charges after we leave the EU.The bloc scrapped them last year, but there have been fears it could cost more to call and use the internet abroad in future.Ministers have said that any increases again would be limited.Brits could be forced to apply for US-style waivers after Brexit to go on their hols, Theresa May has admitted.Unveiling plans last month to pre-screen EU tourists as part of her new post-Brexit immigration policy, the Prime Minister conceded the arrangements were likely to have to be “reciprocal”.The US currently charges  for every ‘ESTA’ waiver form – raising the prospects Brits will be forced to shell out each time they want to fly to the Costa del Sol.The EU are set to decide within weeks whether the Brits will need a visa in the event of No Deal.

title: bikelife bikestormz army gangs
story: Bikestormz - a collection of thrill-seeking young cyclists up and down Britain - is fighting back with the motto BikesUpKnivesDown.Their intervention couldnt come at a more critical time. This week, a boy of  became Britains th stabbing victim this year - and the nations kne crime epidemic has stretched public faith to breaking point.With police and politicians seemingly at a loss with how to stem the flow of blood on Britains streets, the bike community is desperately trying to prove that you can get a bigger adrenaline rush from cycling than crime.Founded in  by Mac Ferrari, a reformed roadman - a young wannabe gangster - at Bikestormzs last London ride out in August police held up traffic, blocked junctions and even cycled alongside the ,-strong mob in an attempt to limit the chaos.Ferrari, a softly-spoken -year-old explains: I have lost too many people I grew up with to murder to prison, he says.Over nine years I lost  friends to gun and kne crime. My best friend was shot dead in a nightclub when I was standing next to him.Others were sent to jail for all kinds of stuff – murder, robbery, drugs. So I wanted to tell the kids to put the kne down and do something more positive.I was tired of people glamorising the lestyle of crime.I wanted to show them you don’t need to get the adrenaline rush from crime you can get the same buzz from riding your bike. Now Bikestormz is like our church.However, unlike kne-wielding, drug-fuelled gangs that force youngers to break the law to progress up a vicious pecking order, this new obsession is saving lives and keeping kids out of serious trouble, Ferrari claims.Anyone who can peddle hard enough to keep up is welcome – no matter their background. Respect is gained by a rider’s skill and range of cycling tricks, rather than their police record.Authority is established through a series of regular skill events. Fighting is not tolerated. Rude and aggressive behaviour is sanctioned... and already, thousands have been inspired to get off their backsides into the saddle.Incredibly, some riders even say that the bike group has brought peace to London estates which were previously at war with each other.Kizzy, an elite rider, , says Bikestormz has even brought peace to warring South London estates.I used to live in Peckham and there was no way I could go to Brixton without someone attacking me,’ he explains.But when you are on your bike there is no problem.When you are riding no one cares where you are from. We are all together. There is something really positive about  or  of us riding together.’Kizzy, a former Deliveroo rider from south London, says he never carried a kne but lots of kids around him did.When I was young I was a right little s**t – stealing bikes, getting into trouble with the police, bad stuff.But after I got into Bikestormz I wised up. And I know so many people who have put down their knives and got into riding. That’s what it’s all about – doing something positive.Founder Mac had already established a reputation as a stunt motorcycle rider when he got back onto his peddle bike and gained followers for the tricks he posted on Instagram.But he could never have expected to find  young riders raring to go when he organised his first ride out from Tower Bridge – an event now immortalised as Bikestormz.I expected about  kids to come together. When I got there, there were . And I was responsible for them all. It was terrying!I told themthere is any fighting there will not be a Bikestormz. And it all went off peacefully. Now we have grown into a massive family.It gives the kids something to occupy themselves. When they are not riding they are doing up and fixing their bikes.Some kids are rude to drivers and pedestrians when we are out but I tell them to stop it. I don’t put up with road rage.Bikestormz represents the UK version of the bike-riding craze known as #Bikele, which was born in the ghettos of Baltimore and Philadelphia.Now the Bikestormz movement has grown into a nationwide phenomenon with kids pulling wheelies and riding in groups up and down the country whenever they have free time.They gather in large groups in parks and quiet roads in industrial estates at weekends or ride around their local area like a mobile gang. Riders join the pack as they see it roll past.They can also be seen practicing tricks on their own or in groups after school wherever there is space.Riding down stairs – no matter how steep or long – is popular too.Meanwhile, bike trick competitions are held in the parks and waste ground in South London throughout the summer.The top riders are selected to join a select group called Street Elite. They are chosen their skills but also or their responsible attitude.To be selected for Street Elite you’ve got to show a good example to the other riders, explains Montana, an -year-old from Lewisham, south-east London.Bikestormz has been a good influence on me. It has kept me away from trouble.Where I live there is a lot of crime and drugs.But riding is a positive thing. Some days I ride from midday until ten o’clock at night. I love it.I first heard about Bikestormz after it started up. I went to a ride out and I haven’t looked back. It has helped me steer away from crime.Founder Mac and his elite riders attract tens of thousands of Instagram follower and get free bikes, trainers and other merch [merchandise] from sponsors.Kizzy added: Being in Street Elite gives us much more exposure.We get bikes from Mafiabikes, trainers from Nike and we have started music videos for London rappers like JME and Macstar.Wheelie Kay@wheelie_kay .k followersFrom the age of nine I started learning how to wheelie, but it was quite hard, so I left it at that. When I ride with my music it just gives me a lot of energy and people love that.Little Harry@littleharry .k followersAs I got older, around , I started watching loads of dferent people on the internet and realisedI keep on practicing I could be like them one day. For me it’s not a hobby, it’s a lestyle and I love what I do.Jake@jake .k followersI’m  and have been riding since I can remember, I’m filled with adrenaline by wheeling through the tightest gaps and going at high speed through traffic!It’s an amazing feeling being surrounded by hundreds of people how share the same passion as you.Ruby@_rubybailey .k followersI have been riding since [I was] two years old. I’m Street Elite’s first girl rider.Riding has become a massive part of my le and I can definitely see a future in it for me.StreeteliteridersThe London traffic will once again be brought to a standstill by teenagers cycling five abreast when the group go out on their next ride out on Christmas Eve.No one knows exactly how many young men and women will turn up at the Tower Bridge starting line at pm on th December.No route has been planned but the cycle caravan will certainly pass Buckingham Palace, go through Hyde Park, possibly down Oxford and even roll on into the City of London. And no one can stop them.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: coastguard border force patrols dover channel
story: The people, believed to be from Iran, were found on the boat after Border Force and HM Coastguard were called about .am.The Border Force vessel and maritime officers were called, helping the migrants ashore.Those on the boat were given a medical assessment and did not require treatment.They will now be interviewed by immigration officials.A HM Coastguard spokesperson said: HM Coastguard is currently assisting Border Force with an incident in the Dover Channel.Locals reported hearing a helicopter overhead during the incident.It comes after four migrants were stranded on an inflatable dinghy in the middle of the English Channel in September last year.The three men and one woman, aged , ,  and , are thought to be from Iran and were spotted by a fishing boat in the English Channel.

title: toby young creepy tech giants social media
story: In fact, it’s when they are at home that they are most at risk — alone in their bedrooms and in front of a screen.Yesterday The Sun told how the ­Children’s Commissioner for England, Anne Longfield, released some hair-raising statistics about how closely ­children are monitored by the increasingly creepy tech giants.By the time the average British child reaches the age of  they are likely to have posted more than , times on social media, providing companies such as Facebook, Pinterest and Instagram with a treasure trove of valuable ­personal ­information about themselves.But it isn’t just the messages they send to each other.Their day-to-day movements are tracked on their phones and smart watches, their school reports are stored on education databases and their digital medical records are kept by the NHS.It’s asthey’re living in , George Orwell’s dystopian novel about the future, except instead of being monitored by the surveillance state, they’re being spied on by hundreds of Big Brothers.And most of them have not got a clue that it’s happening.Last year, the NSPCC published a report showing that  per cent of young people in the UK have taken a naked or semi-naked picture of themselves, which suggests privacy is not uppermost in their minds.I know from personal experience how dangerous this casual attitude to social media can be.At the beginning of the year, I had to step down from a government job and resign from the boards of several ­charities when some silly things I’d said on Twitter were dug up by my enemies.But eventeenagers were aware just how easily their posts could come back to bite them, they probably wouldn’t ­curtail their online activity because tech companies have become masters of getting people hooked on their sites.Sean Parker, founding president of Facebook, let the cat out of the bag, revealing that social media s deliberately set out to turn people into addicts by exploiting their weaknesses.The reason there are “like” buttons, according to Parker, is because every time a user’s post is liked it creates “a social validation feedback loop”.“We need to give you a little dopamine hit every once in a while, because ­someone liked or commented on a photo or a post or whatever,” he said.We already know just how effective these psychological techniques are when it comes to adults.But our children are so much more vulnerable than us adults.Tech companies such as Instagram, Snapchat and Tumblr are supposed to enforce a minimum user age limit of , but few bother — and research suggests three quarters of ten to -year-olds have a social media account. Should parents be worried  Absolutely, say the experts.The National Crime Agency estimates that about , people in the UK pose a threat of some kind to children online — and the number is rising all the time.It adds there has been a  per cent increase in the referrals it has received about people uploading images of child sexual abuse since .Just as alarming is the damaging effect that smartphones and social media have on children’s mental health.According to Jean Twenge, professor of psychology at San Diego State University, the number of US teens who took their own lives increased by  per cent between  and .And , like me, you have a teenage daughter there is even more reason to be worried.Compared to the early s, nearly twice as many American teenage girls now end their own lives. In the UK, a quarter of -year-old girls experienced signs of depression, according to a study of , young people.Overall, Professor Twenge found that the generation she calls “iGen” — those born after  — are much more likely  to suffer from mental health issues than their millennial predecessors.“What happened that so many more teens, in such a short period of time, would feel depressed, attempt ­suicide and commit suicide ” she asks. “The sudden rise of the smartphone.”If you’re not convinced by the advice of the experts, just look at the behaviour of the people who’ve made their fortunes from peddling this digital crack cocaine.Bill Gates, the billionaire founder of Microsoft, stopped his children from owning a phone until they were  and the late Steve Jobs, co-founder of Apple, would not let his kids play on iPads — even though he invented them.Apple recently introduced a new update that tells you how much time you are spending on your screen each day.That’s a step in the right direction, but don’t expect the company to do too much more. Last year, Apple sold nearly a quarter of a billion iPhones, helping to make it the world’s most valuable brand.The leaders of the tech giants are enriching themselves beyond their ­wildest dreams — not just at our expense but at the expense of our children.So it’s pretty clear they won’t be doing anything to help. And that means that, for now, it’s down to us.We have a choice. We do not have to let our children use their services.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says brussels lock uk in forever brexit
story: Diplomats admit to The Sun that the terms of the “Irish backstop” which Theresa May’s Cabinet is poised to back would then be deployed to lock us in its grip permanently.Forget those trade deals with America, China, India, Canada or anywhere .All would be banned.Despite us voting for Brexit. Despite MPs voting to leave the customs union.Despite all the Prime Minister’s ambitious speeches about a global Britain.To get a post-Brexit trade deal, we would have to swallow crippling conditions the EU does not impose on others.Absurdly, it would retain control over the trading policy of the world’s fth largest economy — by then a non-EU member. And, according to Ireland’s cocky PM Leo Varadkar, we would have to stick to all EU rules. Permanently.Can the Tories really sign up to this Or will they stand and fight Some believe we can get out of it all once we have left, next March .We’re not convinced. EvenBritain could, when have we ever done anything but stick slavishly to every letter of our international obligations We are not French, let’s face it.HOW’S this as an excuse for soft justice The Tory “two strikes and you’re out” rule was supposed to mean automatic jail for anyone caught twice with a kne.But hundreds  are still set free by courts ignoring the edict. Now the Tories say “repeat offenders convicted under the ‘two strikes’ rule are  per cent more likely to go to prison than in ”.So it’s “two strikes and you’re slightly more likely to be jailed than before”.No wonder gang members brazenly carry machetes.It’s not just policing that needs radical change — and we welcome Sajid Javid’s claim that signicant new funding is just weeks away.It’s that our courts must get tougher, as a deterrent and to get murderous thugs off the streets.QUELLE surprise! The EU reckons Britain’s economic prospects are worse than those of anyone in its club.And its Remainer stooges pop up like automated bots to carp about their own country being “the sick man of Europe”.That’s the same Europe which has youth unemployment at ,  and . per cent in Spain, Italy and France, compared with our .. And overall unemployment in those countries of ,  and . per cent when ours is four.Of course, the EU’s  forecasters are hardly likely to talk up our prospects.But one thing is clear. Shackle ourselves to their failing model and we’ll fail too.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: heres why you should never call your electrician or plumber mate
story: Small talk - including starting with what about the City game last night, eh  - was also singled out by labourers sick of customers trying to make conversation.Clients have also been called out for trying to put on a working class accent while wheeling out the names of random tools as they chat to tradespeople including roofers, plumbers and builders.Mamta Saha, psychologist at Living Potential International, revealed it was all part of the Chameleon Effect - the act of mimicking someone to make themselves or the other person feel more comfortable. But she warned it would wear thin.Ms Saha said: We naturally feel rapport and connected to people who mirror our body language, tone and the essence of words that we use.We have a natural drive to be liked and subconsciously apply a tinge in our accents or an adjustment in our body languagewe feel it is going to bring us closer to someone ‘understanding us’ and as a result they may feel we ‘understand them’ better, bringing us closer and more connected.The main bugbears of builders revealed they were sick of people assuming they were uneducated - while clients forgot to even offer basic acts of kindness like a glass of water.Tarquin Purdie, who is MD at HaMuch –the website behind the study - said it was understandable why people tried to fit in with their builders.He said: Part of this need to adapt your language is down to not wanting to be ripped off.He said even the assumption that builders took three sugars in their tea and that they loved bacon sandwiches had begun to grate.Mr Purdie added: Hopefully this guide will help both sides of the deal.Householders will feel more comfortable and builders won’t have to drink an endless supply of oversweet tea.The Sun saluted plumber James Anderson, who doesnt charge vulnerable customers in desperate need for his help. In little over a year, he’s provided heating and hot water to  vulnerable people throughout Lancashire, where he now lives, by donating his time and expertise entirely for free.

title: teen cyclist head car overtaking bus
story: A dashcam clip shows the young rider weaving across the road before pedalling hard to catch up with a bus.But instead of squeezing past, he started riding towards traffic on the other side of the road and is struck by a black Vauxhall.The smash was caught on camera by grandfather David Alexander, , who was on a school run in York.David had just picked his granddaughter when he noticed the teenage boy dodging traffic moments before the crash.He said he thought the boy was attempting to overtake a school bus and squeeze in between traffic when he had the crash.He said: He was showing a complete disrespect for any other road user. Just before this happened he nearly hit two girls on the pavement.I couldnt believe what I was seeing. Its an example of why cyclists need proper training from an early age.The footage taken in July last year shows the cyclist come flying off his bike and crashing over the cars bonnet.His bike flies into the air and comes clattering down onto the roof of the car.David pulled over after the incident and offered to supply his dash cam footage to the driver of the black Vauxhall involved in the crash.He says he felt sorry for the driver of the car, a man, who was travelling with his we and two children in the car.He said the cyclist dented the cars windscreen and caused some bodywork damage.David added: You could see that he was trying to race the bus. When I went over after it happened he was staggering around and was dazed.He kept saying hes sorry. Ive got no idea how he managed it. He cant have been looking ahead of him.

title: brits need four hours extra in the day to get everything done do you agree
story: Long hours at work, household chores and looking after the children means people are struggling to tick off the to-do list.According to a poll of , adults,  hours in a day would give them time to actually enjoy their days and get more sleep.Over half of the people surveyed also said that they would like more time to have fun, with six in  saying that they cant recall the last time they had a spare  minutes to do something they really wanted to do.National Geographic have found that on Mars the days are  minutes longer than here on planet earth.And thats unlikely to change anytime soon, but on Mars its a dferent story - a day is  minutes longer than on Earth.Readers might be wondering what good is that is to them, but as our new show MARS reveals, Earthlings could be living on the Red Planet in the not too distant future.As well as sleeping, people said that they would like more me time or time to get into a good book.And perhaps this is because much of the population is exhausted from work - a fth of those polled said they are hindered by an uneven work   le balance.The survey was commissioned to celebrate the second season of MARS which premieres on National Geographic this Sundayat pm.

The Shadow Home Secretary – one of Jeremy Corbyn’s closest allies - said her “suspicion” is that Brits would Brexit all over again at the polls.Speaking on Question Time last night, she said: “I will say this about the second Referendum. You should be careful what you wish for.“If we had a second referendum now the same people who voted leave last time, who are not largely speaking in London, would vote leave again saying: ‘Didn’t youThe comments came just days after Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer reiterated that Labour could back a second Referendum.At Labour Party conference, he said the option of remaining in the EU would be an option on the table.The news came just hours before Jeremy Corbyn told German paper Die Speigel: We cant stop Brexit.He said when quizzed over the issue: The referendum took place. Article  has been triggered. What we can do is recognise the reasons why people voted Leave.Lots of people were angry about the way they had been left behind, he insisted.The Labour boss was also asked about whether he felt sorry for the PM.He replied, hinting she should quit and let Labour take over: I am a decent human being, I feel sorry for anyone in distress. But the best way for anyone to alleviate distress is to take yourself away from the source of it.Business leaders including former BT chair Sir Mike Rake and ex-Sainsbury’s boss Justin King on Thursday called for a second Referendum.The former Sainsbury’s chief said the current choice facing the British public was a “bad Brexit or a disastrous Brexit”.And today Boris brother Jo quit over Brexit too - and also demanded another vote to check whether Leaving was still what the people wanted.

title: when is equal pay day 2018 what does it mean and why are women setting their out of office up
story: Heres what you need to know about Equal Pay Day.Equal Pay Day is essentially when women work for free until the end of the year.This symbolic day is dedicated to raising awareness of the gender pay gap.This year, Equal Pay Day in the UK falls on November .The . per cent figure is calculated by the Fawcett Society using ONS gender pay gap statistics.Earlier this year, gender pay gap reporting regulations meant that companies with more than  employees had to publish figures showing any dferences in pay between men and women.Of those that published data,  per cent pay men more than women,  per cent pay women more and  per cent said they had no gender pay gap.The Fawcett Society is trying to encourage UK workers to talk more openly about their salaries, in a bid to bring an end to pay inequality.Sam Smethers, Fawcett Society chief executive, said: “In workplaces all over the country, pay discrimination is able to thrive and is more common than people realise because of a culture of pay secrecy which persists. People do not know their basic rights and do not know what their colleagues earn.”This year, to help women fight back against gender pay gaps the Fawcett Society has teamed up with employment law charity YESS Law to launch a new Equal Pay Advice Service, paid for by an Equal Pay Fund.In , the Out of Office campaign reached over . billion people, calling for real action on the gender pay gap.Some women would not come into work on Equal Pay Day to prove a point to their employers.Others would set up the notication which said the recipient is in the office, but gave an automatic alert to senders that it’s Equal Pay Day and raises awareness.Many women will be making a point to ask their colleagues what they earn in an effort to improve transparency.Others will be taking to social media to share an equals sign, or post with the #GetEqual and #EqualPayDay tags. Catherine Mayer, co-founder of the Womens Equality Party, tweeted: Ive switched on my #OutofOffice for the rest of   my Twitter isnt working either.Why  Because the #genderpaygap means this is the last day until Jan UK women get paid to work relative to men. The gap is greater for BAME  disabled women.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
